title: Missed Debtor's Exam in Los Angeles, CA
question: Proceedings Held (Proceeding dates listed in descending order)
answers: More facts are needed here. Were you served with documents notifying you of the Judgment Debtor Examination? The Judgment Creditor is required to serve you with a subpoena to appear at a Judgment Debtor Examination. If you were not properly served, you had no reason to appear.

If your noted docket entry is accurate, it gives at least the appearance the matter was stricken. It notes no appearances and off calender. Clearly no one can tell you that is the case from limited second hand information, but it may be you missed nothing, that it was cancelled due to you not being served.

As others have noted however, it is not a matter that will simply disappear.

I would contact the creditor that is attempting to get you to the debtor's examination and see if they will reschedule since you didn't know it was going on--they are just trying to get you there to get you to setup a payment arrangement most likely and to find out where you work/bank, etc. Avoid this if you can and just setup a payment plan.

If you are considering bankruptcy, go and see an attorney now to assist you before you have any more issues with this collector because when they go this far the usually don't stop.
I agree with both attorneys, however I noticed that you also clicked bankruptcy, you may want to sit down with an attorney to discuss bankruptcy options to help with your debt problems.

Atty. Gamez is correct. The other thing that I would suggest is that you check the docket sheet again in a week or so to see what if any additional entries are made as it is possible that a bench warrant can issue from a missed creditor's examination.
